titlestmt.titleproper: Finding Aid for Alfred Ray Canfield papers, 1916-1936.
titlestmt.author: Justin Lee Tyler

repository.corpname: Detroit Public Library. Burton Historical Collection.

did.abstract: This collection contains political correspondence of Alfred R. Canfield and his son, attorney Don W. Canfield.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Born and raised in Portland, Mich., Alfred Ray Canfield started the Clare County Cleaver, a weekly newspaper, at Harrison, Mich. after his graduation from high school. He was later appointed postmaster of Harrison. He and Minnie Orcelia Bogue, of Harrison, married, and they had five children. In 1887, Mr. Canfield moved to Clare, where he founded the Clare Courier. In 1910, Mr. Canfield was appointed tally clerk of the House of Representatives, a position he held for nine years. He then devoted his time to the Courier. He continued as editor and publisher until 1921, when he sold the paper and moved to Detroit. During his career as a country newspaper editor, Mr. Canfield gained a reputation across Michigan. In Detroit, he became secretary of the Democratic State Central Committee, and remained in that position until his death in Sept. 1926 a the age of fifty-nine.

accessrestrict.head: Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: This collection is open for research use.

otherfindaid.head: Other finding aids note
otherfindaid.p: Finding aid and white index cards available in the Burton Historical Collection and on the World Wide Web.

controlaccess.head: Selected Search Terms
controlaccess.p: This collection is indexed under the following headings in the online catalog. Researchers desiring materials about related topics, persons, or places should search the catalog using these headings.
